Award.AwardTitle: AF:III:Small:Collaborative Research: New Frontiers in Join Algorithms: Optimality, Noise, and Richer Languages

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The relational join is central to relational database processing, which is the dominant way data is processed today. The join also models problems in biological and social networks, coding theory, compressed sensing, machine learning, and constraint satisfaction. Recently,  the investigators described the first ever worst-case optimal algorithm (the NPRR algorithm) for join queries.  These new results open a line of new tools to attack a diverse set of fundamental problems related to the join. This project aims to further exploit the new algorithmic techniques developed for NPRR to address the following three classes of problems:

(1) Optimal Join algorithms. Developing algorithms that are instance optimal when the data are stored in either traditional database indexes or new indexing structures is a goal of this project. (2) Coping with and Leveraging Noise. This project will extend the latest work to handle and leverage both worst-case and statistical noise models, bridging to coding theory and compressed sensing.  (3) Expressive Query Languages. The project will explore a series of extensions to join queries that will pave the way to overcome challenges in motif finding, search, databases with functional dependencies, and more powerful classes of queries and join operations.

If successful, the results of this grant will apply to a variety of pattern extraction problems in modern massive, dynamic, and noisy data sets, which have a wide range of applications in complex network analysis, coding theory, and compressive sensing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Business, science, and government depend on efficient data processing. The more data that one can process and the more efficiently, the better decisions, discoveries, and policy one can make. This work described our work on a new, faster algorithms for arguably the most important operator in data processing: the relational join. We showed that our recent theoretical advancements in join processing were also led to dramatically more efficient software prototypes. In addition, we showed deep theoretical connections to other data processing including statistical processing. This holds the potential to provide dramatically more efficient infrastructure.

Intellectual Merit. This project resulted in development of several theoretical papers that deepened our understanding of arguably the most important operator in data processing. We also made connections to areas of geometry and combinatorics, which have proved to be critical to extending the algorithmic insights. 


Broader Impact. Work from this grant has been incorporated into both open source and commercial engines. A paper describing our open source engine, EmptyHeaded, was featured as a best of SIGMOD 2016, the top conference in data management. Three papers won "Best of" awards at major applied and theoretical awards. In addition, it resulted in the training of underrepresented minority groups. One student supported on this award won the SIGMOD undergraduate research award in 2015 for their use of hypergraph methods in query planning.
